awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Conboy at the University of Utah is developing new analytical methods for small-molecule (low molecular weight substances) detection and quantification. Antibodies, with their chemical specificity and high affinity are exceptionally suited for bio-specific detection and quantification. However, utilizing antibodies for the direct label-free detection of low molecular weight substances is a major technical challenge.  Professor Conboy is using nonlinear optical methods to develop a highly sensitive small-molecule immunoassay, providing a reliable, label-free method for detecting and quantifying low molecular weight substances. The research outcome is to provide a set of new highly sensitive analytical tools for the purpose of detection of illicit substances and hazardous substances screening. Integrated within the research objectives is the education of both graduate and undergraduate students in analytical/bioanalytical chemistry, which is of great National importance in maintaining the strength of the US economy and the competitive edge of US biotechnology industries.  Professor Conboy is also involved in hands on demonstrations, science fair activities and assistance with setting up dedicated teaching space for science experiments at local primary schools in the Salt Lake valley with the goal of exposing primary grade students to the wonders of the chemical world and to promote teacher training and introducing young people to the potentials of science.

The scientific goal of the proposed studies is to implement second-harmonic correlation spectroscopy (SHCS) for rapid single point calibration and utilize the high-throughput capabilities of second harmonic imaging (SHI) for screening and quantification. These complimentary techniques, SHCS and SHI have many inherent advantages over existing approaches.  SHCS has the intrinsic advantage that calibration (binding affinity data) can be obtained from a single concentration of the analyte to derive the Kd (or Ka) in a fraction of the time required by a conventional thermodynamic equilibrium binding isotherm measurement, with the added benefit of acquiring both the association and dissociation rates. SHI has the advantage of high-throughput measurement by utilizing antibody capture arrays.  Both methods are also biologically versatile and capable of detecting any molecule containing conjugated structures, including virtually all biomolecules targeted in current assays. Together these methods represent a unique analytical approach that does not compromise sensitivity and speed yet provides a novel, cost effective, and flexible immunoassay format.

por.por_cntn:
Immunoassays, a test used for the detection of a compound (chemical or protein) using antibodies for capture and quantification, for the screening of small molecule drugs are of special interest, as detection and quantification of both prescription and illicit drugs is relevant for toxicological and forensic analysis. Quantification of small molecules has been done through methods such as gas chromatography and mass spectrometry, which are time-consuming and expensive.  Enzyme linked immunosorbent assays (ELISA) utilizing antibodies, are predominantly used in the detection of small molecules in a clinical setting. There are several different variations of ELISAs (sandwich, direct, competitive), which typically use enzymes and chromogenic substrates to ?amplify? the presence of the desired compound, improving the ability to detect low levels (or concentrations) of the material. The simplicity and low cost of ELISAs make this method particularly popular. However, ELISA suffer from poor reproducibility due to nonspecific adsorption of the target compound (antigen) to the antibody sensor surface, insufficient rinsing during washing steps, and variability of incubation time and temperature. Although automation has reduced these effects, other issues such as limit of detection (the lowest amount of material which can be detected) and fixed dynamic range (the response of the test to low and high concentrations of a compound) cannot be overcome easily. ELISAs using fluorescence detection of small molecules have been reported, but labeling of either antigen or antibody can affect the kinetics of the small molecule recognition event or immunoreactivity of the antibody. Another technique for immuno-sensing is surface plasmon resonance (SPR). However, SPR is mass-based which limits its use to antigens with high mass labels or labeling of antibodies.  

Intellectual Merit: Our research which was funded by the NSF focused on developing a novel direct detection immunoassay utilizing the nonlinear optical spectroscopic method of second-harmonic generation (SHG), illustrated in Figure 1.  utilizing three common drugs, cocaine, methadone, and morphine. These drugs were used as test cases for detection of small molecules in a direct primary antibody immunoassay. Cocaine is most well-known for its use as a recreational drug. Methadone and morphine are both opioids which are known to bind to μ-opioid receptors. Methadone has been used to treat withdrawal from addictive opioid abuse and morphine is commonly used to relieve pain. All three of these drugs are thought to act upon the central nervous system and are highly addictive. These properties make them common targets in drug testing and antibodies for these species are readily available. Additionally, the binding interactions of cocaine and morphine with their respective antibodies have been characterized previously. Numerous studies using ELISA, SPR, and fluorescence have demonstrated detection in cocaine, methadone, and morphine immunoassays. However, these studies involve labeling of the drug or antibody and indirect detection of the drugs. The result of our NSF funded research clearly demonstrated the direct detection SHG immunoassay to be far superior to existing clinical assays with improved detection limits, higher sensitivity and rapid analysis times. 

Boarder Impacts: The work funded by the NSF is the first demonstration of the label-free direct detection of small-molecules using a SHG biosensor, which outperforms the current gold standard ELISA in both sensitivity and selectivity. The ability to detect small-molec ules (low molecular weight chemical compounds) has direct relevance in the fields of medicine, environmental screening of toxins, and chemical warfare agent detection, to name just a few. Utilizing the intrinsic selecting of antibodies, a whole host of agents could be detected.  Key to mission of the NSF funded research was the educational directive to also modernize the analytical chemistry curriculum and educate students for their future careers. New materials and ideas were infused into the chemistry curricula to expose students to bioanalytical techniques. The large number of established biotechnology firms and is reflective of the need for technically skilled worked in the area of bioanalysis.  The students who worked on the research described above obtained the essential training and expertise in cutting edge bioanalytical methods, fulfilling a National need for chemists and biologists with increased familiarity with bioanalytical techniques which is of increasing importance as researcher delve deeper into the biological origins of disease and the quest to find drugs and therapeutics.
